Hi JUnit,

Here's a blog entry that describes in detail what I ended up doi=
ng to get non-static inner classes instantiated and run along with their en=
closing class:

http://cleveralias.blogs.com/thought_spearmints/2009/06/run=
ning-nonstatic-inner-classes-of-junit-tests.html

Thanks again for the disc=
ussion and assistance.

--p

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Paul Holser" <p=
holser@...> wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@> wr=
ote:
> > > I wonder if this would be useful functionality for JUnit to
> > =
> have in general: when a test class is detected, and that test class has
>=
 > > non-static inner classes which may themselves be test classes, when
> =
> > building up tests for the enclosing class, also instantiate the inner
>=
 > > test classes and attach to the (an?) enclosing test class instance. I
=
> > > saw some previous discussion about such fixtures in JDave.
> > 
> > I=
 think there were two different directions going on here.  It sounds
> > li=
ke you want JUnit, when given the outer class, to automatically
> > instant=
iate the inner classes.  It sounded like JDave wanted JUnit,
> > when given=
 the inner class, to automatically consult the outer class
> > when instant=
iating.
> > 
> > Am I getting both requests right?  If not, then we're gett=
ing close to
> > a Rule of Three threshold for reuse.  If I am, then I see =
the same
> > Java idiom having two different "obvious" interpretations to t=
wo
> > different classes of user.
> 
> David, I believe you're getting both=
 requests right.  In my case, the inner classes are to be instantiated alon=
g with the enclosing class when the enclosing class is run, but never insta=
ntiated and run on their own.  I ended up accomplishing this via the AllTes=
ts runner and suite() methods that adapt the enclosing class and inner clas=
s instances as JUnit 3.8-style Test adapters.  I also wanted to tie the inn=
er class instances to a specific enclosing class instance, because the inne=
r classes use fixture fields from an enclosing instance.
> 
> It looks as t=
hough the requirement for JDave inner class contexts is that they be instan=
tiable and runnable on their own, independent of their sibling contexts -- =
and that the requestor would have liked for such contexts to adopt whatever=
 Runner a @RunWith on the enclosing class might have specified.
> 
> Off th=
e top of my head, I can't think of a clean way for JUnit to support both st=
rategies in the core proper.
> 
> I may try satisfying my specific use case=
 in another way, perhaps using an as-yet-developed kind of Runner.  The All=
Tests way still seems a bit icky, but works for now.
> 
> Thanks,
> Paul Ho=
